Award.AwardTitle: AEMB 2016 Conference Grant; October 5-8, 2016; Minneapolis, MN

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Proposal No: 1643343 -
PI: Murray, Teresa

NSF has made an award in support of travel for undergraduate students to attend the AEMB (Alpha Eta Mu Beta, the National Biomedical Engineering Honor Society) Annual Meeting and MINDS (Mentoring for INnovation Design Solutions) Workshop being held in Minneapolis, MN, Oct. 5-8, 2016, at the same time as the Biomedical Engineering Society (BMES) 2016 Annual Meeting. Students, preferably junior undergraduates, will be recruited through over 40 AEMB chapters. Students applying for the workshop will identify an unmet need for a biomedical device or technology (innovation) and its potential impact. Awardees will be selected based on the quality and novelty of the design idea and their potential impact. Workshop participants will be assigned to teams consisting of approximately 4 students and a team mentor. The teams will work together while at the workshop to identify design considerations, use online sources and upload ideas and considerations to their own collaboration site. The teams will be encouraged to meet virtually for up to 6 months after the workshop ends to further refine their innovation. This highly innovative workshop format will build necessary engineering design skills including 5 key considerations that are not usually stressed in coursework projects: i) market considerations for commercialization, 2) establishing methods for testing the product, 3) quality control requirements for production, 4) regulatory strategy, and 5) evaluating prospects for intellectual property protection. Students will learn how to effectively communicate with teammates and mentors who are from other schools and organizations using collaborative online tools. The proposal also includes detailed assessment plans, including surveys at the end of the workshop and at the end of the projects. Videos and written promotions will be evaluated to determine level of understanding of the 5 key design considerations. The program is expected to develop a core group of engineers who will better understand the importance of considering human needs before attempting design devices and who will be better equipped to work in the increasingly virtual environment that requires communication between distant facilities and customers. Key elements of the workshop are expected to be adopted by BME programs. A white paper describing the workshop organization and outcomes will be produced.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Alpha Eta Mu Beta (AHMB) is the international biomedical engineering honor society, and it was established to recognize and encourage excellence in the field of Biomedical Engineering and Bioengineering, and to promote a greater understanding of the profession. AHMB’s “Mentoring for INnovative Design Solutions” (MINDS) Scholar Program is an innovative approach that provides biomedical engineering students with the opportunity to collaborate and network with peers and mentors across the country for a 5-month period, while building necessary engineering design skills. Although students learn about the design process in their college coursework, there are several areas that are not always sufficiently emphasized in a typical engineering program, for instance (1) market considerations for commercialization (why is this product needed, what market is there for it, how big is the market expected to be, etc.),  (2) regulatory strategy (what regulations does the product need to meet in order to be approved for sale, and how can the design team plan for a successful strategy to get their product approved), and (3) evaluating prospects for intellectual property protection (how can the design team protect others from using their idea or copying their product).

Having these skills is very important for future engineers in order to be able to design products that can successfully reach the public. In order for biomedical engineers to address public healthcare needs, they need to have the knowledge and skills to navigate every step and aspect of bringing a product to market. During the program, MINDS Scholars enhance their knowledge of product design as described above, but they also learn how to effectively communicate with teammates and mentors from other schools and organizations using collaborative online tools, which are becoming an increasingly important skill in today’s work environment.

Participation in the MINDS Scholar Program is through a competitive application process, and students need not be AHMB members to participate, as all biomedical engineering majors are eligible. Each annual MINDS Scholar Program starts with an in-person workshop, where students meet their team members and mentors, and create an action plan for their participation in the program. They select a central design idea that will be refined during the 5-month period, and then they periodically communicate to advance the project forward, culminating in a final report in the form of a website, a presentation, or a written report.

In the 2016-2017 program, there were 21 students and 7 mentors. By the end of the program, participants were able to create a novel product idea, describe how they used the key design considerations in the product design process, and were able to state the features, benefits and impacts of their products through production of a promotional presentation. Product ideas varied widely and included an implantable glucose monitor, a newborn monitoring device, an anesthesia machine, a wearable air filter system, a diagnostic app, an innovative mattress system for patients who are bedridden, and a tissue-engineered skin substitute.

Students were surveyed at the beginning and the end of the program. The results showed that a majority of students agreed or highly agreed that the MINDS program had improved their perceived skills in their following areas: understanding the design considerations addressed in the program and applying them to any project, assessing product requirements, explaining key features of a project, collaborating remotely, and working in a team. Many students also reported that MINDS had impacted their career goals. The results of the 2016-2017 program, and feedback for students and mentors, were used to improve the program for future cohorts.

Some quotes from 2016-2017 students were as follows:

“This program provided an excellent and unique opportunity to work on a project with individuals from different backgrounds and geographies. This project provided an opportunity to improve my ability to communicate clearly, particularly regarding technical matters. Additionally, I have gained a deeper appreciation for the market research necessary as well as the product development and regulatory strategy.”

 “The MINDS program has advanced my interest in the biotech industry, specifically in the R&D department. It has directionally helped me choose what kind of internship/graduate programs I want to look for in order to enhance my future success.”

“I've learned plenty of new concepts, however, I gained a lot of new knowledge on the business side of engineering. My professional skills have increased five-fold due to the diverse range of subjects studied through this program.”

“It was good practice for complete thinking when I get into the workforce.  It allowed for the practice of the complete engineering process (minus manufacturing) which is invaluable before going into the workforce.”

 

In summary, we achieved our aims of teaching students how to integrate market needs, regulatory considerations, and intellectual property strategy into the design process. In doing this, we also increased their awareness of how biomedical devices and technologies can benefit society.
